content: The 112th Congress used TPA authority to pass implementing bills for U.S. FTAs with Colombia, Panama, and South Korea in 2011. Other trade negotiations that may require TPA include the Doha Development Round, TPP, TTIP, and TISA. Congress has granted the President TPA/fast track authority for over 40 years. The President has been granted Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) for over 40 years, allowing for expedited consideration and unamended voting on trade agreement implementing legislation. TPA balances Congress's constitutional authority over trade policy while giving the President negotiating leverage with U.S. trade partners. The Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) has been granted for over 40 years, allowing expedited consideration of trade agreements by Congress. Earlier versions of TPA were adopted with bipartisan support, but as trade negotiations have become more complex, renewal of TPA has become more controversial. The expiration of TPA raises questions about its renewal and form, reflecting decades of debate and compromise between Congress and the executive branch. The Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) has evolved over time, highlighting the partnership between Congress and the President in trade policymaking. The U.S. Constitution grants Congress authority over foreign trade regulation, emphasizing the need for cooperation to negotiate trade agreements effectively. The relationship between the two branches can be strengthened or strained based on political and economic conditions. Article I, Section 8 grants Congress the power to regulate commerce with foreign nations and collect taxes. The President has authority to negotiate treaties and international agreements under Article II. Both legislative and executive branches are involved in developing and executing U.S. trade agreements. Congress historically set tariff rates on imported products for the first 150 years of the United States. Congress historically had authority over foreign trade through setting tariff rates on imported products, which was the main trade policy instrument and a key source of federal revenue. Early trade debates in Congress often involved Members from northern manufacturing regions advocating for protectionist tariffs, while those from southern commodity exporting regions pushed for lower tariffs. The President's role in trade policy was primarily focused on negotiating and implementing bilateral treaties of friendship, commerce, and navigation, with the Senate's advice and consent, which included commitments to most-favored-nation treatment. In the 1930s, the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act imposed high tariffs, leading to retaliatory measures by trade partners and worsening the Great Depression. The Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act of 1934 (RTAA) was developed in response to the damaging effects of the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act in the 1930s. It authorized the President to enter into reciprocal trade agreements to reduce tariffs, marking the first time Congress delegated expanded trade authority to the President. Under the Trade Expansion Act of 1962, Congress granted the President authority to negotiate tariff reductions and submit agreements for congressional review. This allowed the President to conclude the GATT Kennedy Round, focusing on tariff reduction agreements. The GATT member countries reached agreements in the Kennedy Round related to nontariff barriers (NTBs), including a customs valuation agreement and an antidumping agreement that would have required changes in U.S. laws and regulations beyond tariff modifications. Changes in U.S. law or regulations beyond tariff modifications led Congress to believe the President had overstepped his authority. A resolution in 1966 instructed the Johnson Administration against negotiating "nontariff commitments," but when ignored, Congress refused to implement the NTB changes. This set the stage for the creation of fast track authority for trade agreements, as future multilateral trade agreements would increasingly focus on nontariff barrier rules, necessitating changes in U.S. law for compliance. The Trade Expansion Act of 1962 expired in 1967, prompting Congress to seek a legislative remedy for presidential encroachment on legislative authority. The House Ways and Means and Senate Finance Committees hold "mock markups" on informal drafts of implementing legislation, voting to approve or disapprove.
